reviewText: DVD was great. Enjoyed the videos immencely. Would definately put Route 66 on my bucket list now for sure.
kitschy and cool but really outdated film quality. Its really more of a content issue. looks like 1990s PBS quality...
Too much time spent on interviews.  Interesting but not vital.
This wasn't as interesting as I thought it would be.  No subtitles or closed-captioned.
too many interviews and not enough scenery

This is an up to date review of what used to be route 66.  It centers on a luxury motorhome which is pictured on the back cover.  The 56? Ford pictured on the front cover did not appear in the segments we watched.  There was very little mention of the old route 66 that we used to travel and love in the 1950s and 1960s.

A lot of people talking about Route 66. Not the road trip I was expecting. Also, each disk is a stand alone segment with the intro repeating on each one - not a seamless itinerary.  It's informative but not as entertaining as I had hoped.
Strange that it focused more on Illinois than it did the western end.
It has some nice clips but some of the interviews get a little long-winded.

The interviews and information are from 2003!!  Not helpful if not current.
We are planning a trip next month and I had to do additional research to see if the places/restaurants/hotels were still in operation.
The opening 5-minutes of repeated information was boring.
I did like the large map and postcards, the DVDs - very disappointing.
A little different than I thought it would be.

Too many and too long interviews with people along the route. Would prefer to have more scenic and geographical oriented views of road and towns it passes thru. This video seemed more like advertising the RV used for the documentary. The huge, heavy RV can't possibly travel over some significant parts of the old road such as Sitgreaves Pass in Arizona which the video barely touched on.

Fabulous!!!!  Just like being there in person. My trip is planned for July 24th and I feel like I know all the great places to go to and step back it time.
So gla I got the DVD's

One version did offer the option of starting in California instead of Chicago.  The others were a pain as you had to work from the back of the book forward.  But all helped us to understand the importance and history of Route 66.
